H0.text: To form a good hypothesis, the student should perform the experiment in three trials, measuring the average time it takes for a toy car to travel 10 meters.

H1.text: Increasing the accuracy of the results is the reason the student should perform the experiment in three trials when measuring the average time it takes for a toy car to travel 10 meters.

H2.text: To make the results more significant, a student performs the lab investigation by measuring the average time it takes for a toy car to travel 10 meters in three trials.

H3.text: To better explain the investigation to others, it is best for the student to perform the experiment measuring the average time it takes for a toy car to travel 10 meters in three trials.

A4.text: In engineering, precision is often taken as three times Standard Deviation of measurements taken, representing the range that 99.73% of measurements can occur within.

A5.text: increasing the sample size generally increases precision but does not improve accuracy
